data.text:
Like English, Danish is a Germanic language. This means that both languages share similar characteristics that can make learning Danish a relatively easy task for English speakers. When it comes to grammar, some aspects of the Danish language are even more simple than their English equivalents. Take verb forms as an example. While English has 16 different verb forms, Danish has only nine. Intonation (the “musical tone” of a language) is another point where English and Danish differ, since Danish sounds a lot flatter than English. On the other hand, there is a significant overlap in the vocabulary of both languages, so English speakers are often able to identify several words in Danish phrases.

Embrace global citizenship through Danish phrases

Unlock a world of possibilities with just a few basic Danish sentences. While Danish may pose challenges for English speakers, a bit of focus will help you effortlessly learn essential phrases for greeting locals, ordering food, and navigating. Even just covering these categories will enhance your travel experience in Denmark. Speaking Danish also provides a valuable foundation for exploring other Scandinavian languages, like Norwegian and Swedish.

Forge connections. Learning useful phrases and engaging in local language can be a wonderful way to make new friends. With relatively few people learning Danish as a second language, locals appreciate and readily assist those who make the effort, showcasing cultural awareness.

Career opportunities. Denmark's strong economy and progressive societal values make it an appealing destination. Mastering Danish adds a unique edge to your resume, opening doors to a world of new opportunities in this forward-thinking society.

Basic Danish phrases

Hello, how are you? — Hallo, hvordan går det?

What is your name? — Hvad hedder du?

My name is… — Jeg hedder…

Do you speak English? — Taler du engelsk?

How much is it? — Hvad koster den?

Where can I find an ATM? — Hvor er der en pengeautomat?

Can I see the menu? — Kan jeg se menuen?

Please — Vær så venlig
